Situation1: They are asked to take part in an important family event like a holiday celebration or trip.
Situation2: They skim a recent pharmacy newsletter while on break to see what new drugs have been released.
Story: I sat at the kitchen table, my phone buzzing with messages from my family group chat. My sister was excitedly planning our annual holiday trip, and everyone expected me to help organize the details and be present for every moment. I could hear my mom’s voice in my head, “It’s important for us to be together.” But as I tried to focus on the conversation, my mind kept drifting back to the pharmacy newsletter I’d skimmed during my lunch break. There was a new drug release, and my manager had stressed the importance of staying updated for patient safety. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in—my family needed me to be the supportive, involved sister, while my profession demanded I keep learning, even if it meant sacrificing personal time. My heart ached with guilt as I realized I couldn’t give my all to both. I stared at the screen, torn between replying to my family and diving deeper into the newsletter, feeling the tension build inside me as I wrestled with what to do next.
